text: with Dr. Barbara Wolfe addresses successful

text: FOLLOW-UP: A KEY COMPONENT OF SUCCESSFUL TRAINING
label: BODY

text: Dr. Barbara Wolfe, a trainer-of-trainers exemplar,
label: BODY

text: is currently on the faculty of the Department of
label: BODY

text: Special Education at the University of Wiscon-
label: BODY

text: sin-Eau Claire. Prior to university teaching, she spent
label: BODY

text: fifteen years providing inservice training on inclusion to
label: BODY

text: early childhood professionals. We would like to share some
label: BODY

text: of Barbara's thoughts on training gleaned from a recent
label: BODY

text: You have conducted research on best practices in
label: BODY

text: inservice education. What did you find most helped
label: BODY

text: teachers implement new ideas in their classrooms?
label: BODY

text: Factors that most helped teachers use new ideas in their
label: BODY

text: content that addressed an existing need. (3) follow-up
label: BODY

text: support, (4) practical content that could be applied immedi-
label: BODY

text: Did any of these findings surprise you?
label: BODY

text: Two were surprisingthe importance of handouts (i.e.
label: BODY

text: practical. relevant handouts) and the impact of the trainer
label: BODY

text: on inservice outcomes. Participants defined effective
label: BODY

text: trainers as knowledgeable, well prepared, credible, enthusi-
label: BODY

text: astic and able to use a variety of techniques including
label: BODY

text: hands-on and interactive strategies. The good news about
label: BODY

text: these characteristics is that people can learn themthat is.
label: BODY

text: training isn't an inherent trait but rather a learned skill.
label: BODY

text: Let's talk for a minute about follow-up support. Could
label: BODY

text: you define what you mean by follow-up?
label: BODY

text: Broadly speaking, follow-up can be defined as strate-
label: BODY

text: gies and events that take place following the planned
label: BODY

text: workshop experience. Some examples are a "back home"
label: BODY

text: plan to try on the job, a follow-up class or workshop, on-
label: BODY

text: site coaching by peers or trainers or a follow-up letter with
label: BODY

text: Why do you think follow-up is so important in
label: BODY

text: Learning is a process, not something that happens in a
label: BODY

text: one-time training event. Change takes place over time and
label: BODY

text: requires a focused effort for new ideas to be integrated into
label: BODY

text: ongoing practice. Follow-up provides a strategy for focused
label: BODY

text: effort over time, thereby increasing the chance that new
label: BODY

text: ideas will actually become on-the-job behaviors.
label: BODY

text: What follow-up strategies have you found to be most
label: BODY

text: In my research, not too many participants had experi-
label: BODY

text: enced follow-up but those who had preferred (1) observing
label: BODY

text: someone else demonstrating the new idea, (2) having on-
label: BODY

text: the-job assistance or (3) participating in small group
label: BODY

text: discussions with fellow staff or an administrator.
label: BODY

text: Two other specific follow-up strategies that can be
label: BODY

text: offered to participants on a voluntary basis are: (1) coach-
label: BODY

text: ing (peer or expert coaching) which is a labor intensive,
label: BODY

text: one-on-one strategy where the coach serves as a mirror
label: BODY

text: through which the teacher can examine her behavior, and
label: BODY

text: (2) peer support group which brings participants back
label: BODY

text: together to talk about the successes they have experienced
label: BODY

text: and to brainstorm solutions that support implementation
label: BODY

text: Earlier you spoke of "back home" plans as a follow-
label: BODY

text: up strategy. Can you expand on that?
label: BODY

text: A "back home" plan is like a personal learning plan. It
label: BODY

text: is a good strategy for intensive full-day or multi-day
label: BODY

text: classes. Each individual completes a plan indicating
label: BODY

text: personal goals, what they will do to accomplish their goals,
label: BODY

text: and possibly, products that will demonstrate accomplish-
label: BODY

text: ment. Trainers can get feedback on the participants'
label: BODY

text: progress toward their goals by doing follow-up visits,
label: BODY

text: calling the site, or requesting video or written records.
label: BODY

text: It is sometimes difficult to motivate participants to
label: BODY

text: complete a back home plan after a long training day, so I
label: BODY

text: have tried using an "Aha" sheet where participants write
label: BODY

text: down new ideas throughout the session. Then when they
label: BODY

text: make their plan, I have them limit their ideas to 3 or 4
label: BODY

text: things to try at home. We usually take up to a half-hour at
label: BODY

text: the end of the training course to develop an individual or
label: BODY

text: team "back home" plan. Carry-over is sometimes increased
label: BODY

text: by having participants verbally report their plan to someone
label: BODY

text: else, or to the whole group. Somehow when you say it
label: BODY

text: aloud, you feel more committed to action.
label: BODY

text: Is there anything else you would like to say?
label: BODY

text: Helping teachers learn new skills and incorporate them
label: BODY

text: into the classroom requires an intensive system of training
label: BODY

text: that utilizes multiple training strategies, including opportu-
label: BODY

text: nities to observe, practice, receive feedback and talk about
label: BODY

text: the ideas. It is paramount that administrators are committed
label: BODY

text: to both the ideas being presented and the training design,
label: BODY

text: which might require an increase in release time for training,
label: BODY

text: EMPOWERING PARENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN INCLUSION TRAINING
label: BODY

text: day care and other providers of services to children. This
label: BODY

text: training, designed and conducted primarily by experi-
label: BODY

text: enced parent advocates, was funded by the Partnerships
label: BODY

text: for Inclusion Project at the Frank Porter Graham Child
label: BODY

text: Development Center at the University of North Carolina
label: BODY

text: The parents participating in the project represented a
label: BODY

text: variety of socio-economic and family backgrounds, had
label: BODY

text: children with different disabilities, and were located
label: BODY

text: throughout the state. The parents agreed to participate in
label: BODY

text: a two-day training session and follow-up activities.
label: BODY

text: Expenses and a small honorarium were given to partici-
label: BODY

text: The training sessions and follow-up activities were
label: BODY

text: designed to develop the participants' advocacy and
label: BODY

text: presentation skills by focusing on the following:
label: BODY

text: a working knowledge of the state's service delivery
label: BODY

text: the ability to effectively present a personalized
label: BODY

text: a working knowledge of the basic rights of children
label: BODY

text: the ability to work effectively within the system in
label: BODY

text: Several of the sessions focused on giving parents a
label: BODY

text: variety of "tools" to present their unique perspective on
label: BODY

text: children's books and artwork, visual images and adult
label: BODY

text: education principles to support presentations. Adult
label: BODY

text: learning principles included giving audiences informa-
label: BODY

text: tion they could use (relevance), showing how the
label: BODY

text: information could be used to solve problems (practical-
label: BODY

text: ity) and convincing audiences of the need to learn
label: BODY

text: The parents left the two-day training with an "indi-
label: BODY

text: vidualized education plan" to help develop their presen-
label: BODY

text: tations. This written plan outlined the presentation
label: BODY

text: pieces that were in place, i.e., the "strengths," and the
label: BODY

text: pieces that needed to be developed, i.e., the "needs." As
label: BODY

text: follow up, smaller groups met with one of the parent
label: BODY

text: advocates. At these sessions, each parent trainee give a
label: BODY

text: presentation. The other trainees and the parent-advocate
label: BODY

text: acted as an audience of professionals who critiqued each
label: BODY

text: presentation. This role playing helped prepare the
label: BODY

text: trainees to present information before live audiences and
label: BODY

text: to answer probing questions. The inclusion specialists
label: BODY

text: now serve to link the parents to day care and related
label: BODY

text: Ralph C. Worthington, Sandy Steele andKatherine Favrot
label: BODY

text: families and providers have led to subsequent projects to
label: BODY

text: assist preschool personnel in serving children with
label: BODY

text: disabilities. One of the biggest challenges facing com-
label: BODY

text: munity program inclusion efforts is providing the help
label: BODY

text: that is needed when it is needed. Although training
label: BODY

text: typically addresses many of the providers' anticipated
label: BODY

text: needs, unanticipated needs inevitably arise as services
label: BODY

text: are delivered to children and families.
label: BODY

text: To respond to providers' needs in a timely manner,
label: BODY

text: we have found no substitute for "being there." When
label: BODY

text: someone with special expertise in serving children with
label: BODY

text: disabilities and their families is present on a daily basis,
label: BODY

text: she/he can most easily develop the working relationships
label: BODY

text: necessary to help teams provide effective services.
label: BODY

text: Although on-site support is our preferred form of
label: BODY

text: technical assistance, we must often seek alternatives due
label: BODY

text: to factors such as time and distance. After a good
label: BODY

text: working relationship has been established, an itinerant
label: BODY

text: person can offer assistance using telecommunication
label: BODY

text: who then support the inclusion of
label: BODY

text: on the belief that all children with disabilities deserve
label: BODY

text: the option of attending community programs with their:
label: BODY

text: non-disabled peers. It is committed to supporting child
label: BODY

text: care personnel in their collaboration with other service
label: BODY

text: providers to meet the needs of all children in inclusive
label: BODY

text: options such as the telephone. For example, during
label: BODY

text: a weekly phone call to each site, the SIP consultant
label: BODY

text: and provider reviewed each child's progress and
label: BODY

text: But sometimes a picture is needed to establish
label: BODY

text: the context in which the problem occurs. Two
label: BODY

text: strategies have proven advantageous in this situa-
label: BODY

text: tion. One is to "dialogue" through a videotape
label: BODY

text: exchange. First, the provider makes a video demon-
label: BODY

text: strating the problem and then the trainer responds
label: BODY

text: by making a video that demonstrates an alternative
label: BODY

text: practice. In the Early Ed Project, video exchange
label: BODY

text: helped providers increase child engagement in
label: BODY

text: small group activities by demonstrating alternative
label: BODY

text: all parties to see what is happening as well as to
label: BODY

text: talk about it. Using the state's educational televi-
label: BODY

text: sion network, a speech and language pathologist in
label: BODY

text: a television studio watched two children in pre-
label: BODY

text: schools several hundred miles away. She gave the
label: BODY

text: providers suggestions to stimulate language and
label: BODY

text: then followed up weekly through videotape ex-
label: BODY

text: change. These alternatives allow us to deliver
label: BODY

text: personalized help in a timely manner without
label: BODY

text: spending hours traveling from program to program.
label: BODY

text: hopes, Trainees are asked to think about inclusion from
label: BODY

text: a personal perspective by remembering and describing a
label: BODY

text: time in their lives when they wanted to belong and felt
label: BODY

text: excluded. People describe powerful childhood memories
label: BODY

text: about being ridiculed in kindergarten, being excluded
label: BODY

text: from a team, and/or being teased about their ethnicity.
label: BODY

text: Through this exercise they remember the hurt of exclu-
label: BODY

text: sion and they begin to empathize with the feelings of
label: BODY

text: Next, participants complete a survey that asks them
label: BODY

text: to rate their responses to a series of statements about
label: BODY

text: E3 The parents of a child with disabilities should be able
label: BODY

text: to decide what placement and services their child
label: BODY

text: O For most children with disabilities inclusion works
label: BODY

text: only if there is extra adult help.
label: BODY

text: CI Inclusion is good for children with disabilities but the
label: BODY

text: other children usually do not benefit.
label: BODY

text: Teaching children with disabilities is much harder than
label: BODY

text: O Some children would be better off in separate more
label: BODY

text: The group then discusses the range of responses. Be-
label: BODY

text: cause there are no right or wrong answers, this exercise
label: BODY

text: helps people clarify their own values and beliefs and
label: BODY

text: share their thinking with their colleagues. Teaming is
label: BODY

text: vital to the success of inclusion and this exercise also
label: BODY

text: helps the trainees understand and respect the values and
label: BODY

text: By working through this process of examining and
label: BODY

text: experiencing the power of attitudes and values about
label: BODY

text: disabilities, the teams come to a common core of beliefs
label: BODY

text: about inclusion. Team members then write a mission
label: BODY

text: statement that will serve to guide their goals and activi-
label: BODY

text: ties as they plan for inclusion.

text: The Community Integration Project (CIP), a federally funded
label: BODY

text: outreach project sponsored by The George Washington
label: BODY

text: University, supports the inclusion of children with disabilities
label: BODY

text: in early childhood programs. CIP assists LEAs and early
label: BODY

text: childhood programs in combining resources and acquiring
label: BODY

text: This newsletter was developed under grant number H024D10019 with the
label: BODY

text: CIP/The George Washington University Information Line
label: BODY

text: As communities strive to increase inclusive
label: BODY

text: options in early childhood education, the need
label: BODY

text: to pull together fragmented systems has raised
label: BODY

text: new issues for planners and practitioners. Rejoining a
label: BODY

text: fragmented system is not an easy task. Typically, a
label: BODY

text: community may begin by establishing an interagency
label: BODY

text: group with the mission of coordinating services to
label: BODY

text: families. This type of cooperative initiative simply
label: BODY

text: coordinates existing services and offers a reasonable
label: BODY

text: starting point for change. However, in localities where
label: BODY

text: the need and intent is to fundamentally change the ways
label: BODY

text: services are designed and delivered, a
label: BODY

text: partnership will be collaborative or coopera-
label: BODY

text: tive in nature depends on "how far partners
label: BODY

text: wish to move beyond the status quo"
label: BODY

text: The existence of a common goal or
label: BODY

text: vision supports the notion of fundamental
label: BODY

text: change and is a defining feature of a true
label: BODY

text: that collaborating parties express their personal beliefs
label: BODY

text: and build consensus around the issue they wish to
label: BODY

text: address. Participants in this process are challenged to
label: BODY

text: transcend their traditional roles and answer the question
label: BODY

text: "What do we want to create?" rather than "What do we
label: BODY

text: think we can do?". As service delivery barriers are
label: BODY

text: broken down, there is an opportunity to create an
label: BODY

text: inclusive vision and to have a collaboration where the
label: BODY

text: whole becomes greater than the sum of the parts. Senge
label: BODY

text: (1990) in his book The Fifth Discipline, states that a
label: BODY

text: shared vision can "create the spark, the excitement that
label: BODY

text: lifts an organization out of the mundane, . .. compel
label: BODY

text: courage so naturally that people don't even realize the
label: BODY

text: Collaboration may not always start with a clear
label: BODY

text: vision, but rather begin with a sense that something
label: BODY

text: needs to happen differently. The vision may not be
label: BODY

text: clearly articulated for some time. Vandercook, York
label: BODY

text: and Sullivan (1993) warn that engaging in a long-term
label: BODY

text: commitment without taking the time to build relation-
label: BODY

text: ships can be futile. Collaborations are fostered by
label: BODY

text: encouraging participants to work together on small
label: BODY

text: projects: offering opportunities to share philosophies,
label: BODY

text: learning to communicate effectively and experiencing
label: BODY

text: small successes. Collaboration is basically a people-to-
label: BODY

text: people process. It is essential to create strong bonds and
label: BODY

text: mutual respect between the collaborative partners as a
label: BODY

text: first step in building a shared vision.
label: BODY

text: Creating a meaningful vision is an exciting and
label: BODY

text: challenging task. To effectively sustain the commitment
label: BODY

text: of the collaborative partners to change, a shared vision
label: BODY

text: must include the deeply personal visions of each
label: BODY

text: participant as well as mutually held beliefs. When this
label: BODY

text: happens, a vision will be seen as both "my vision" and
label: BODY

text: restructunng, suggests that change requires visions that
label: BODY

text: (1) are compelling, (2) are clear and (3) can be assessed.
label: BODY

text: "We will send a man to the moon in this decade" is a
label: BODY

text: classic statement of a vision that exemplifies
label: BODY

text: these criteria. So too are the visions "all
label: BODY

text: children can learn" or "all children can learn
label: BODY

text: in school environments that are fully
label: BODY

text: such as these can change the way a
label: BODY

text: Collaboration is a process: it is not an end in itself.
label: BODY

text: A collaborative effort will look different each time it is
label: BODY

text: implemented. A specific model of collaboration cannot
label: BODY

text: be "parachuted" into a state, community or classroom. It
label: BODY

text: must be responsive to the culture of each new location
label: BODY

text: relationship-oriented and like all lasting relationships
label: BODY

text: Meeting House Cooperative Preschool is a
label: BODY

text: collaboration with the Alexandria City Public Schools,
label: BODY

text: has offered inclusive placements for children with
label: BODY

text: disabilities. These children and their teachers are
label: BODY

text: provided support by a special educator from the
label: BODY

text: school system, who is on site at least two days per
label: BODY

text: week. Partnerships between the regular and special
label: BODY

text: educators require a variety of skills. In particular,
label: BODY

text: Building rapport is an essential first step in
label: BODY

text: establishing good communication. At Meeting House,
label: BODY

text: initial meetings between the regular and special
label: BODY

text: educators focused on sharing vital information (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: Occasionally forms (e.g., role exchange form) were
label: BODY

text: used to expedite these discussions. In addition, team
label: BODY

text: members worked to develop a personal relationship.
label: BODY

text: Limited free time was used to engage in casual
label: BODY

text: conversations about ideas and concerns, helping to
label: BODY

text: Teamwork requires flexibility in both principles
label: BODY

text: and practices. Regular and special educators often
label: BODY

text: view issues that arise in inclusive programs from
label: BODY

text: distinct perspectives. Being willing to reflect on
label: BODY

text: differences and remain open to adapting one's
label: BODY

text: practices helps to create a team approach. In one
label: BODY

text: Meeting House class, a child with disabilities was
label: BODY

text: having extreme difficulty during circle time. While the
label: BODY

text: classroom teacher did not want this child to be
label: BODY

text: separated, she agreed to the special educator's plan to
label: BODY

text: pull the child out of circle time. The time was used to
label: BODY

text: facilitate skills the child needed to participate in group
label: BODY

text: time and eventually he was able to join in circle time.
label: BODY

text: Support among team members is a basic
label: BODY

text: ingredient in successful collaborations. When there
label: BODY

text: are problems to be solved, they are tackled together
label: BODY

text: with each member contributing ideas and resources. In
label: BODY

text: order to recognize problems as well as progress, goals
label: BODY

text: must be defined. Goals may reflect objectives for
label: BODY

text: children or next steps necessary for team
label: BODY

text: development. With goals firmly in mind, the
label: BODY

text: challenges can be identified and addressed, and the
label: BODY

text: small steps made toward improvement can be
label: BODY

text: being supportive enabled the Meeting House staff to create
label: BODY

text: a shared vision and meet the challenges the inclusion
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: to do this is by developing a mission

text: while avoiding obstacles such as premature

text: this time, goals should be formalized and

text: Innovative Practices for Young Children at the University
label: BODY

text: A major goal of the project is to promote inclusion in
label: BODY

text: education and non-education settings throughout a
label: BODY

text: community. This goal has prompted a unique aspect of the
label: BODY

text: projectthe establishment of local Inclusion Networks.
label: BODY

text: An Inclusion Network is comprised of citizens represent-
label: BODY

text: ing a variety of organizations reflecting each community's
label: BODY

text: unique strengths and resources. Network membership
label: BODY

text: usually includes parents, educators, health professionals,
label: BODY

text: social service providers, clergy, business persons and local
label: BODY

text: government officials. The Inclusion Network meets over a
label: BODY

text: period of twelve to eighteen months (four or five meet-
label: BODY

text: ings) to carry out the following project-related activities:
label: BODY

text: the development of a Community Vision Statement
label: BODY

text: the identification of Issues and Barriers to inclusion

text: The success of the Inclusion Networks has been
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: work with a broad coalition of community members; the
label: BODY

text: opportunity to consider new and different ways to address
label: BODY

text: issues and barriers; and productive, fast paced meetings.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The function and outcomes of Inclusion Networks
label: BODY

text: differ from formal networks such as local interagency
label: BODY

text: coordinating councils. By combining existing local
label: BODY

text: associations and informal/formal networks associated with
label: BODY

text: early childhood special education programs and agencies,
label: BODY

text: Inclusion Networks have established and promoted
label: BODY

text: inclusive practices across communities. The activities of
label: BODY

text: each Network seem to have a ripple effect. Members
label: BODY
